units.title: Advanced Functions
units.description: Analyze polynomial, rational, and piecewise functions in depth.

content.explanation: End behavior depends on degree and leading coefficient. Even degree: both ends same direction. Odd degree: ends opposite. Positive leading coeff: right side goes up. Turning points ≤ degree-1. Zeros where graph crosses x-axis.
content.real_world: Roller coaster designers use polynomial graphs to plan hills and valleys.

content.explanation: Vertical asymptote: denominator=0 (factor doesn't cancel). Horizontal asymptote: compare degrees. Same degree: ratio of leading coefficients. Numerator degree < denominator: y=0. Numerator degree > denominator: no horizontal (may have oblique).
content.real_world: Asymptotes model diminishing returns in economics and drug absorption in medicine.

content.explanation: Piecewise: different formulas for different x-intervals. Evaluate by finding which piece applies. Absolute value: |x|=x if x≥0, |x|=-x if x<0. |ax+b|=c gives ax+b=c or ax+b=-c.
content.real_world: Tax brackets are piecewise functions — different rates for different income ranges.

content.explanation: Composition: (f∘g)(x)=f(g(x)). Order matters: f∘g ≠ g∘f usually. Decomposition: express a complex function as a composition of simpler ones. If h(x)=(2x+1)³, let g(x)=2x+1, f(x)=x³, then h=f∘g.
content.real_world: Data encryption applies function composition — encode then decode.

units.title: Polynomial and Rational Analysis
units.description: Zeros, multiplicity, partial fractions, and polynomial inequalities.

content.explanation: A zero with multiplicity m: if m is odd, graph crosses x-axis. If m is even, graph touches and bounces. Fundamental Theorem of Algebra: degree n polynomial has exactly n zeros (counting multiplicity, including complex).
content.real_world: Signal processing uses polynomial zeros to filter specific frequencies.

practice_problems.question: x⁵ has degree 5. Total zeros (with multiplicity)=___
f(x)=(x-4)². The zero x=4 has multiplicity ___

content.explanation: To solve f(x)>0: 1) Find zeros. 2) Plot on number line. 3) Test each interval. 4) Include zeros for ≥ (not for >). Sign changes at odd-multiplicity zeros.
content.real_world: Engineers solve inequalities to find safe operating ranges for machinery.

practice_problems.question: x²-9>0. Zeros: x=±3. Solution: x<-3 or x>___

content.explanation: To solve f(x)/g(x)>0: find zeros of numerator AND denominator. Plot on number line. Test intervals. Never include values where denominator=0.
content.real_world: Dose-response curves in pharmacology use rational inequalities for safe ranges.

practice_problems.question: At denominator zero, the function is:

content.explanation: Complex zeros of polynomials with real coefficients come in conjugate pairs: if a+bi is a zero, so is a-bi. Use this to build polynomials from zeros. A degree-n polynomial with real coefficients can have 0, 2, 4, ... complex zeros.
content.real_world: Signal processing uses conjugate pairs to ensure real-valued output signals.

practice_problems.question: If 2+3i is a zero, so is 2-___i
Zeros: 1, -1, i, -i. Degree must be at least ___
A degree 3 polynomial can have 2 complex zeros.
Degree 5 with real coefficients: possible # of complex zeros?
If 1-i is a zero, conjugate is 1+___

questions.question: If 4+i is a zero, so is 4-___

units.title: Exponential and Logarithmic Applications
units.description: Advanced exp/log equations, modeling, and natural logarithms.

content.explanation: When bases don't match, take log of both sides. 2ˣ=7 → x=log(7)/log(2)≈2.807. General: bˣ=c → x=ln(c)/ln(b). For e-based: eˣ=c → x=ln(c).
content.real_world: Radiocarbon dating solves exponential equations to find artifact ages.

content.explanation: Convert to exponential: log_b(x)=c → x=bᶜ. Combine logs first: log(A)+log(B)=log(AB). Check solutions: argument must be positive. Extraneous solutions may appear.
content.real_world: Seismologists solve log equations to calculate earthquake energy from magnitude.

content.explanation: Growth: A=A₀eᵏᵗ (k>0). Decay: A=A₀eᵏᵗ (k<0). Half-life: t₁/₂=ln(2)/|k|. Doubling time: t=ln(2)/k. Logistic growth: P=M/(1+ce⁻ᵏᵗ) approaches carrying capacity M.
content.real_world: Epidemiologists use logistic models to predict pandemic curves.

practice_problems.question: Half-life 10 yrs. After 20 yrs, fraction remaining=1/___
100 bacteria double every 3 hrs. After 6 hrs: ___

content.explanation: Periodic: A=P(1+r/n)^(nt). Continuous: A=Pe^(rt). P=principal, r=annual rate, n=compounds/year, t=years. APY=(1+r/n)^n-1 for effective annual rate.
content.real_world: Every savings account, mortgage, and loan uses compound interest formulas.

units.title: Advanced Trigonometry
units.description: Inverse trig, law of sines/cosines, identities, and polar coordinates.

content.explanation: sin⁻¹(x): domain [-1,1], range [-π/2,π/2]. cos⁻¹(x): domain [-1,1], range [0,π]. tan⁻¹(x): domain all reals, range (-π/2,π/2). These give the principal value (one specific angle).
content.real_world: GPS systems use inverse trig to calculate bearing angles between coordinates.

content.explanation: Law of Sines: a/sinA = b/sinB = c/sinC. Use when you know AAS, ASA, or SSA. Law of Cosines: c²=a²+b²-2ab·cosC. Use when you know SAS or SSS. Ambiguous case (SSA): may have 0, 1, or 2 solutions.

examples.problem: Triangle: a=7, b=8, C=60°. Find c.
Triangle: a=3, b=4, c=5. Find C.

content.real_world: Surveyors use law of sines and cosines to measure distances across rivers and valleys.

practice_problems.question: a/sinA=b/sinB. If a=10, A=30°, B=60°: b=10sin60°/sin30°=___
Use Law of Cosines when you know:
practice_problems.hint: Need two sides and included angle.

lessons.title: Sum, Difference, and Double Angle Formulas

content.explanation: sin(A±B)=sinAcosB±cosAsinB. cos(A±B)=cosAcosB∓sinAsinB. Double: sin2A=2sinAcosA. cos2A=cos²A-sin²A=2cos²A-1=1-2sin²A. Half: sin(A/2)=±√((1-cosA)/2).
content.real_world: Wave interference in physics uses sum and difference formulas to combine signals.

content.explanation: Point (r,θ): r=distance from origin, θ=angle from positive x-axis. Convert: x=rcosθ, y=rsinθ. Reverse: r=√(x²+y²), θ=arctan(y/x). Same point has multiple representations: (r,θ)=(-r,θ+π).
content.real_world: Radar systems use polar coordinates to track objects by distance and angle.

content.explanation: Standard form: (x-h)²+(y-k)²=r². Center (h,k), radius r. General form: x²+y²+Dx+Ey+F=0. Complete the square to convert. Two circles intersect if |r₁-r₂| < d < r₁+r₂.
content.real_world: Cell tower coverage areas are modeled as circles on maps.

content.explanation: Standard form: (x-h)²/a²+(y-k)²/b²=1. Center (h,k). If a>b: horizontal major axis, vertices (h±a,k), foci (h±c,k) where c²=a²-b². If b>a: vertical major axis. Eccentricity e=c/a (0<e<1).
content.real_world: Planets orbit the sun in ellipses, with the sun at one focus (Kepler's 1st law).

content.explanation: Vertical: (x-h)²=4p(y-k). Opens up if p>0, down if p<0. Focus at (h,k+p). Directrix y=k-p. Horizontal: (y-k)²=4p(x-h). Opens right if p>0, left if p<0. Focus at (h+p,k). |p|=distance from vertex to focus.
content.real_world: Satellite dishes and car headlights use parabolic shapes to focus signals and light.

practice_problems.question: Parabola focus and directrix are equidistant from:

content.explanation: Standard form: (x-h)²/a²-(y-k)²/b²=1 (horizontal) or (y-k)²/a²-(x-h)²/b²=1 (vertical). c²=a²+b² (note: PLUS). Asymptotes: y-k=±(b/a)(x-h) for horizontal. Eccentricity e=c/a>1.
content.real_world: LORAN navigation uses hyperbolas formed by time differences of radio signals.

units.title: Sequences and Series
units.description: Arithmetic, geometric, and other sequences; sigma notation; convergence.

content.explanation: Arithmetic: constant difference d. aₙ=a₁+(n-1)d. Sum: Sₙ=n(a₁+aₙ)/2=n/2(2a₁+(n-1)d). Gauss's trick: pair first and last terms.
content.real_world: Stacking objects (like cans in a pyramid) follows arithmetic series.

content.explanation: Geometric: constant ratio r. aₙ=a₁·rⁿ⁻¹. Finite sum: Sₙ=a₁(1-rⁿ)/(1-r). Infinite sum (|r|<1): S=a₁/(1-r). If |r|≥1, infinite series diverges.
content.real_world: Compound interest is a geometric sequence — each year multiplies by (1+r).

content.explanation: ∑ᵢ₌₁ⁿ aᵢ means a₁+a₂+...+aₙ. Properties: ∑(aᵢ+bᵢ)=∑aᵢ+∑bᵢ. ∑caᵢ=c∑aᵢ. Key formulas: ∑i=n(n+1)/2. ∑i²=n(n+1)(2n+1)/6. ∑1=n.
content.real_world: Computer science uses summation to analyze algorithm efficiency (Big O notation).

content.explanation: (a+b)ⁿ=∑ₖ₌₀ⁿ C(n,k)·aⁿ⁻ᵏ·bᵏ. C(n,k)=n!/(k!(n-k)!) = 'n choose k'. Pascal's Triangle gives coefficients. (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b². (a+b)³=a³+3a²b+3ab²+b³.
content.real_world: Probability calculations use binomial theorem for success/failure experiments.

units.title: Vectors and Matrices
units.description: Vector operations, dot product, matrix operations, and determinants.

content.explanation: A vector has magnitude and direction: v=⟨a,b⟩. Magnitude: |v|=√(a²+b²). Add: ⟨a,b⟩+⟨c,d⟩=⟨a+c,b+d⟩. Scalar multiply: k⟨a,b⟩=⟨ka,kb⟩. Unit vector: v/|v|.
content.real_world: Forces in physics are vectors — direction and strength both matter.

content.explanation: u·v=a₁a₂+b₁b₂. Also u·v=|u||v|cosθ. If u·v=0, vectors are perpendicular (orthogonal). cos θ=u·v/(|u||v|). The dot product is a scalar, not a vector.
content.real_world: Work in physics is a dot product: W=F·d (force dot displacement).

practice_problems.question: If dot product = 0, vectors are perpendicular.

content.explanation: Add/subtract: element by element (same dimensions). Scalar multiply: multiply every element. Matrix multiply: dot product of rows × columns. AB ≠ BA generally. Dimensions: (m×n)(n×p)=(m×p).
content.real_world: Computer graphics use matrices to rotate, scale, and translate 3D objects.

practice_problems.question: For AB to exist, columns of A must equal:
practice_problems.hint: Columns of A = Rows of B.

content.explanation: 2×2 determinant: |a,b;c,d|=ad-bc. If det≠0, matrix is invertible. Inverse of [a,b;c,d]: (1/det)·[d,-b;-c,a]. det=0 means no inverse (singular matrix). Cramer's Rule uses determinants to solve systems.
content.real_world: Cryptography uses matrix inverses for encoding and decoding messages.

units.title: Limits and Introduction to Calculus
units.description: Concept of limits, evaluating limits, continuity, and rates of change.

content.explanation: lim(x→c) f(x) = L means f(x) gets close to L as x gets close to c. The function doesn't need to be defined at c. Left limit (x→c⁻) and right limit (x→c⁺) must agree for the limit to exist.
content.real_world: Speed at an instant is a limit of average speed over shrinking time intervals.

practice_problems.question: If left≠right limit:
practice_problems.hint: Must agree for limit to exist.

content.explanation: Direct substitution: plug in c. If 0/0 (indeterminate): factor, rationalize, or simplify. Limits at infinity: divide by highest power. Leading terms dominate. lim(x→∞) p(x)/q(x): compare degrees.
content.real_world: Engineers evaluate limits to determine maximum stress a material can handle.

content.explanation: f is continuous at c if: 1) f(c) exists, 2) lim(x→c)f(x) exists, 3) lim(x→c)f(x)=f(c). Types of discontinuity: removable (hole), jump, infinite (asymptote). Polynomials are continuous everywhere.
content.real_world: Smooth animations in games require continuous functions — no jumps or breaks.

practice_problems.question: f(x)=(x-2)/(x-2) at x=2: type of discontinuity=___

lessons.title: Average and Instantaneous Rate of Change

content.explanation: Average rate of change = (f(b)-f(a))/(b-a) = slope of secant line. Instantaneous rate = lim(h→0)(f(x+h)-f(x))/h = slope of tangent = derivative. For f(x)=x², derivative=2x. This is the foundation of calculus.
content.real_world: Speed is instantaneous rate of change of position — the basis of physics.

practice_problems.question: Instantaneous rate is the slope of:
